snippet: The move elevated the standing of the extremist Haqqani faction, but was rejected by the late leader Mullah Omar’s son, threatening a split within the group.
abstract: Taliban announces on website Shahamat that longtime deputy Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour has become supreme leader and names two deputies drawn from group's Haqqani wing; move strengthens Haqqani network, which is listed by United States as terrorist group, and threatens rift in Taliban as Mullah Yaqoub, son of former leader Mullah Muhammad Omar, had sought role for himself.

byline.original: By TAIMOOR SHAH and ROD NORDLAND
byline.contributor: Taimoor Shah reported from Kandahar, and Rod Nordland from Kabul, Afghanistan. Joseph Goldstein, Ahmad Shakib and Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul.

lead_paragraph: The move elevated the standing of the extremist Haqqani faction, but was rejected by the late leader Mullah Omar’s son, threatening a split within the group.

headline.main: Taliban Pick New Chief and 2 Hard-Line Deputies
